body: Amid glistening greens and pyramids of produce in the small store in Flushing, Queens, that he hoped would insure his family's prosperity, Sun Yong Back assesses a future that has suddenly dimmed. The odds seem as long as his workdays. As New York City's economy turned anemic, he says, his sales have dropped by more than 30 percent. Taxes are
title: Korean Entrepreneurs Find Their Dream Is Tarnishing

body: Two men were burned in a fire ignited by candles on a Christmas tree in a Brooklyn apartment, Fire Department officials said yesterday. "It's still a tradition for some people to put lighted candles on a tree," said a department spokesman, Lt. Frank Martinez. "Last night the tradition caught up with them." He said Ayrton Goncalves, 26 years old,
title: Candles on Tree Cause a Fire

body: Wedged between two decidedly New York thoroughfares, Eastern Parkway and Flatbush Avenue, is the facade of a plantation home behind rust-colored brick and six white columns. It is surrounded by hundreds of poinsettias, camellias and calla lilies. All this is indoors, on display in the Steinhardt Conservatory of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. While
title: Sunday Outing; Brooklyn Garden Becomes The South

body: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved substantial cuts in service on New York City's subways and buses and the Long Island Rail Road for 1991. But the service reductions were not as severe as those that had been proposed. That is because transit officials, bowing to pressure from the public and M.T.A. board members, decided
title: Milder Transit Service Cuts Are Approved

body: In the cramped Soleil Restaurant in Manhattan, behind steaming dishes of conch and red snapper and piles of rice and red beans, emotions soared yesterday as Haitians celebrated the victory of a man some called Haiti's Mandela or Martin Luther King Jr. Taxi drivers, engineers, students, they pounded the tables of the restaurant at 10th Avenue and
title: In the U.S., Haitians Take Their Joy to the Streets

body: For $30, Shimon Wojsfeld, owner of Kaufman Trimming at 459 Broadway, could have gotten rid of his garbage. "The guy comes by in his truck and I ask, 'aren't you on strike?' " Mr. Wojsfeld said. "He wanted to make a couple of bucks on the side." Mr. Wojsfeld declined the offer. Four days after 2,100 private sanitation workers walked out against 475
title: Rising Piles of Garbage Test Business Owners' Wits

body: The powerful Speaker of the New York State Assembly, Mel Miller, was indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on Federal fraud charges that involved the buying and selling of cooperative apartments in New York City. The 19-count indictment charged Mr. Miller and a top aide, Jay Adolf, with fraud between 1984 and 1986 when they were partners in the law firm
title: New York Assembly Speaker Is Indicted in Co-op Deals

body: Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker and New York State's second most powerful Democratic official, said tonight that he and a top aide would soon be indicted on Federal mail-fraud charges. The charges, people close to the Speaker said, stem from two real-estate deals that Mr. Miller and the aide, Jay E. Adolf, are said to have participated in as
title: New York Assembly Speaker Says He and Aide Face Fraud Charges

body: THE Long Island Rail Road, beset by a budget gap of $27 million and a shrinking ridership attributed to "the unexpected depth of the recent downturn in our region's economy," is planning to cancel 60 trains a day and close Pennsylvania Station and the Flatbush Avenue terminal in Brooklyn from 1:30 A.M. to 4:30 A.M. The cuts would go into effect on
title: L.I.R.R. Planning To Drop 60 Trains

body: The Long Island Rail Road announced a number of moves yesterday to close a $27 million budget gap. They include cutting 60 trains and closing Penn Station at times. . title: L.I.R.R. Will Reduce Service

body: In a white brick synagogue near his boyhood home in Brooklyn, Rabbi Meir Kahane was eulogized yesterday as a holy man who, like the prophets of old, was often shunned by his people. title: Grief and Anger at Kahane's Funeral

body: Maybe it was Samuel Robinson, a 37-year-old homeless man, who best summed up the spectator appeal of yesterday's marathon. He watched it in Harlem, in front of the Handmaids of Mary Convent at 15 West 124th Street, standing in a soup-kitchen line with dozens of people clapping and screaming at the runners, "Pump it up, man!" and "You can do it!"
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON; Support On Street Is Very Generous

body: It was just a single handwritten note, scrawled in broken English and found on the ground in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. body: Hoping to prevent the violence and vandalism that have marred recent Halloweens in New York City, the police have assigned extra officers to patrol around schools and shopping areas today, and special units will be watching for roving bands of youths like those who rampaged through the city's streets last year. title: Police and Schools Try to Head Off Halloween Trouble

title: DAILY NEWS DROPS UNION EMPLOYEES
